This withdrawal is carried out by the police, because it is considered a serious offence. For any serious offence, your licence can be taken away on the spot. 2. In a built-up area, a 30-zone, or a residential area, if you exceed the speed limit by more than 30 km/h, you risk a driving ban pronounced by the judge in court. Depending on the ruling, you may be prohibited from driving any motor vehicle (even those not requiring a licence) for a period ranging from at least 8 days up to 5 years. For novice drivers (less than 2 years with a full category B licence), the rules are even stricter.
optionb: An immediate withdrawal of your driving licence.
optionc: You will have to appear in court.

q: At the top right, a sign warns drivers that the car's lights must be on. But which lights ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - When the dipped headlights (or the main beams) are on, the two parking lights at the front and the two red lights at the rear are also lit. The dipped headlights must be on: During the day: in rain, when visibility is less than 200 meters; in fog, when visibility is less than 200 meters; in snowfall, when visibility is less than 200 meters; or in other conditions (e.g. smoke from a fire) when visibility is less than 200 meters, such as in this tunnel.

q: May the driver of the car overtake the cyclist on the left at this intersection ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - At an intersection where right-of-way from the right applies, a cyclist may be overtaken on the left. When overtaking a cyclist (or moped) on the left, the driver must leave: 1 meter of lateral distance in built-up areas. 1.5 meters outside built-up areas.
optiona: No, because it is an intersection with right-of-way from the right.
optionb: Yes, if he leaves 1.5 meters of lateral space.

q: The saliva test is positive. How many hours of temporary driving ban do you immediately receive ?
e: Alcohol - Drugs - During a saliva test, a cotton swab is used to scrape saliva from the mouth to determine the presence of drugs. If the result exceeds the legal limit: you must immediately hand over your driving licence for 12 hours. An immediate withdrawal of the licence is also possible. After 12 hours, a new saliva test follows. Offenders also risk heavy fines and a driving ban of up to 5 years. Refusing the saliva test = immediate 12-hour driving ban. The saliva test may only be carried out if the police suspect drug use.

q: You drive past the first sign. Which sign will you most likely see next ?
e: OBLIGATORY DIRECTION - The first sign means: End of priority road. So at the next intersection, you will have to yield the right of way. Sign 1: Mandatory direction. Sign 2: One-way street. Sign 3: Right-of-way from the right

q: After drinking a lot of alcohol, what actually lowers your blood alcohol level ?
e: Alcohol - Drugs - There are no medicines or tricks to lower your blood alcohol level. The only solution is to wait until your body has processed the alcohol and you are sober again.
optiona: Taking medication prescribed by my pharmacist.
optionc: Waiting, only time reduces your blood alcohol level.

q: What should you do in a long tunnel to stay safe ?
e: Accidents - If a tunnel is longer than 500 meters, it is indicated by this road sign. Inside a tunnel, it is usually darker than outside on the road. That's why you should remove your sunglasses and switch on your dipped headlights well before entering. In a tunnel, it is forbidden to: park or stop, make a U-turn, or drive backwards.
optiona: Pay close attention to where the emergency exits are.

q: An intersection without traffic signs. The priority-to-the-right rule applies. The truck is moving slowly onto the intersection, ready to turn left. May the grey car overtake it on the right at the intersection ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - What the traffic rules say: Normally, overtaking is done on the left. Exception: overtaking is allowed on the right when the driver to be overtaken has signaled the intention to turn left and has moved to the left side to perform this maneuver. Overtaking on the left at intersections where the priority-to-the-right rule applies is prohibited, except in this specific case.

q: The driver of the grey car is driving at this intersection behind the truck, which is moving slowly. Is the grey car allowed to overtake the truck on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - There are no traffic signs at this intersection. Therefore, the rule of priority to the right applies. Overtaking on the left is prohibited at this intersection. The only exception: a cyclist may be overtaken.

q: What is the maximum allowed speed in Flanders until the end of 2026 past this sign ?
e: SPECIAL PLACES - The sign indicates the beginning of a residential zone. According to the new highway code, which will (likely) come into effect in October 2026, the maximum speed in a residential zone in Flanders will then be reduced to walking pace.

q: Is this car allowed to park at that spot in this residential area ?
e: SPECIAL PLACES - In a residential area, cars may only park in places specifically designated for parking. They may be parked on either the left or right side of the roadway, depending on the direction of traffic.
optiona: No, it must park on the shoulder.
optionc: Yes, because it is parked close to the edge of the roadway.

q: Is this car allowed to park at that spot in this residential area ?
e: In a residential area, cars may only park in places specifically designated for parking. They may be parked on either the left or right side of the roadway, depending on the direction of traffic.
optiona: No, it must park on the shoulder.
optionc: Yes, because in a residential area, you are allowed to park on the left or right side of the roadway.

q: When you see this traffic sign, you know ...
e: Accidents - The upper sign indicates that the tunnel is at least 500 meters long. The exact length can be shown on the upper sign. The additional sign indicates that the tunnel starts in 200 meters.
optiona: ... that the tunnel is 200 meters long.
optionb: ... that the tunnel is 500 meters long.

q: After which sign do you know that the tunnel has a length of 700 meters ?
e: Accidents - The first sign indicates that a tunnel of 500 meters starts 700 meters further. The exact length of the tunnel can be shown on the sign itself. In this case, 700 meters.

q: When you see this road sign, you know ______
e: Accidents - The exact length of a tunnel can be indicated on the sign. In this case, 700 meters.
optiona: ______ that the tunnel is 700 meters long.
optionb: ______ that there is a tunnel 700 meters ahead.

q: An accident without injuries at an intersection within a built-up area. You have already placed a warning triangle. What do you do next ?
e: Accidents - In the case of a minor accident without injuries, you should try to clear the intersection. If that is truly impossible and the cars block the intersection, then you notify the police.
optiona: You try to park the cars in a safe place.
optionc: You leave the cars where they are, and fill in the European accident report.

q: May a smartphone be used as a GPS in the car ?
e: TECHNIQUE - Using a smartphone as a GPS is allowed, as long as the device is placed in a fixed holder. Of course, you may only hold the smartphone in your hand when you are stopped or parked.
optionc: Yes, if it is placed in a fixed holder.

q: Traffic is moving very slowly. Is this lady allowed to quickly call her employer, to say that she will arrive a bit later ?
e: TECHNIQUE - Electronic devices such as a phone, tablet distract the driver. That is why drivers are not allowed to use, hold or manipulate a mobile electronic device with a screen while driving, unless the device is placed in a proper holder attached to the vehicle. Electronic devices may be used when the car is standing still or parked. But stopping at a traffic light or in a traffic jam is not considered as standing still'

q: Where are you not allowed to overtake a cyclist on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - In or before a dangerous bend, it is forbidden to overtake on the left a team (e.g., horse and cart), a vehicle with more than two wheels, or a two-wheeled motor vehicle. But when visibility is very poor, you are also not allowed to overtake a cyclist.
optiona: In a dangerous bend with very poor visibility.
optionb: At an intersection with priority of the right.

q: An intersection without traffic signs. The white car wants to turn left. The grey car wants to turn right. Who has the right of way ?
e: PRIORITY WHEN TURNING OFF - The grey car is turning right and taking the shorter turn. It has the right of way.
optionc: Whoever turns first automatically has the right of way.

q: An intersection without traffic signs. The white car wants to go straight ahead. The grey car wants to turn left. Who has priority ?
e: PRIORITY WHEN TURNING OFF - Traffic going straight has priority over traffic that is turning.

q: An intersection without traffic signs. The driver of the white car stops briefly at the intersection and then wants to drive straight ahead. But the grey car suddenly turns left.
e: PRIORITY WHEN TURNING OFF - Traffic going straight has priority over turning traffic. Even if the driver of the white car stops briefly, he keeps his priority.
optiona: That is allowed, because the grey car comes from the right.
optionb: That is allowed, because the white car stopped.
optionc: That is not allowed, because the white car goes straight on.

q: The grey car quickly reversed at this intersection because the white car was approaching at high speed. But who has the right of way here ?
e: Priority from the right - At an intersection where no authorised person, traffic lights or road signs regulate priority, the priority to the right applies. The grey car comes from the right and therefore has priority. The white car should have stopped.
optiona: The white car, because it goes straight ahead.
optionb: The grey car, because it comes from the right.

q: The driver of this car is waiting for her friend in this residential area. Is the car parked correctly ?
e: Waiting and Parking - In a residential area, you may only park in the designated parking spaces provided for that purpose.
optiona: Yes, because the car is in front of the traffic sign.

q: The driver of this car is waiting for her friend within a built-up area. Is the car parked correctly ?
e: Waiting and Parking - A broken white line divides the roadway into lanes. This means that parking on the roadway is not allowed. You may stop only briefly to let someone get in or out. Waiting for someone counts as parking.
optiona: Yes, because the car is in front of the traffic sign.

q: The driver of this car is waiting for her friend within a built-up area. Is the car parked correctly ?
e: Waiting and Parking - In that place, this car is allowed to park or stand still on the roadway.
optiona: Yes, because the car is in front of the traffic sign.

q: The driver of the car has stopped to let the child get in. Is that allowed at this place ?
e: Waiting and Parking - There is a broken white line between the traffic lanes. That means parking is not allowed there. But stopping to let someone get in is allowed.

q: Is this car correctly parked in this 30-zone ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - Vehicles must be parked on the right side of the roadway, in the direction of travel.

q: You have stopped at the stop line. To whom must you give way ?
e: CROSSING AND TRAFFIC SIGNS - A STOP means you must come to a complete stop at the stop line and yield to drivers who are on the public road you want to enter. If there is no stop line on the road surface, you must stop at the sign. If there are no drivers on the crossing road, you still have to make a full stop before entering the intersection.
optionb: To drivers on the crossing road.

q: The driver of this car wants to turn right at this intersection. Is he in the correct lane position ?
e: PRIORITY WHEN TURNING OFF - This driver must position himself as far to the right as possible on the road when he wants to turn right.

q: The driver of this car saw no other road users and carefully entered the intersection without stopping. Was he allowed to do that ?
e: CROSSING AND TRAFFIC SIGNS - A STOP means you must come to a complete stop at the stop line and yield to drivers on the public road you want to enter. If there is no stop line on the pavement, you must stop at the traffic sign. Even if there are no drivers on the crossing road, you must still come to a complete stop before entering the intersection.
optiona: Yes, because there is no stop line on the road.
optionb: Yes, because he is turning right.

q: The driver of this car saw no other road users and carefully entered the intersection without stopping. Was he allowed to do that ?
e: CROSSING AND TRAFFIC SIGNS - A STOP means you must come to a complete stop at the stop line and yield to drivers on the public road you want to enter. If there is no stop line on the pavement, you must stop at the traffic sign. Even if there are no drivers on the crossing road, you must still come to a complete stop before entering the intersection.
optiona: Yes, because there is no stop line on the road.

q: A driver has to make a long trip abroad. How often should he ideally take a break ?
e: During a long car journey, it is recommended to take a short break of at least 15 minutes about every two hours to prevent fatigue and stay alert. Make sure to get out of the car, stretch your legs, take deep breaths, and stay hydrated with water or light snacks.

q: A driver has to make a long trip abroad. How often should he ideally take a break ?
e: STOPPING DISTANCE - During a long car journey, it is recommended to take a short break of at least 15 minutes about every two hours to prevent fatigue and stay alert. Make sure to get out of the car, stretch your legs, take deep breaths, and stay hydrated with water or light snacks.

q: A one-way street in a built-up area. Is this car parked correctly ?
e: WAITING AND PARKINGOn a one-way street, a vehicle may be parked on either the left or the right side of the carriageway.
optiona: Yes, it may be parked on the left or right side of the carriageway.
optionb: No, it must be parked on the right side of the carriageway.

q: Is this car parked correctly ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - The car is parked before the blue sign with the letter P. At that point, the roadway is still divided into lanes with a broken line. Parking is only allowed after the sign.

q: What is the maximum allowed speed for this car on this road in Wallonia ?
e: SPEED - There are 2 x 2 lanes, separated by a central reservation. The maximum allowed speed in all regions, outside built-up areas, is 120 km/h.

q: What is the maximum permitted speed for the motorcycle on this N-road in Flanders ?
e: SPEED - An N-road is considered an ordinary road. In Flanders and in the Brussels Region, the maximum permitted speed on an ordinary road is 70 km/h. In Wallonia, it is 90 km/h.

q: How old must you be to take the theoretical exam for a category B driving licence ?
e: DRIVING LICENCE - As soon as you are 17 years old, you may take the theory exam in an official exam centre. To pass, you need to score at least 41 out of 50 points.

q: From what age can you start learning to drive a car in Belgium ?
e: DRIVING LICENCE - GENERAL From the age of 17, and after passing the theory test, you may start learning to drive a car with a driving school or with an accompanying instructor.

q: From what age can you take the practical driving test for licence B in Belgium ?
e: DRIVING LICENCE - GENERAL As soon as you are 18 years old, you can take the practical driving test for licence B in an examination centre, provided that your training period meets the legal requirements.

q: Just before entering this tunnel, it suddenly starts to rain heavily. Which lights do you use when driving inside the tunnel ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - Inside the tunnel, it is quite dark and visibility is less than 200 meters. Therefore, you must drive with your dipped headlights on. Inside the tunnel it does not rain, so the fog lights are not used.
optionb: The dipped headlights and the rear fog light.
optionc: The dipped headlights, the rear fog light, and the front fog lights.

q: On the way, it rained heavily. Finally, this driver reaches the tunnel.  With which lights does he continue his ride in the tunnel ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - Inside the tunnel, it is quite dark and visibility is less than 200 meters. Therefore, you must drive with your dipped headlights on. Inside the tunnel it does not rain, so the fog lights are not used.
optionb: The dipped headlights and the rear fog light.
optionc: The dipped headlights, the rear fog light, and the front fog lights.

q: What is the maximum permitted speed for the motorcycle on this ordinary road in Wallonia ?
e: The Lanes - On an ordinary road in Wallonia, the maximum permitted speed is 90 km/h. But there is a traffic sign indicating that the maximum permitted speed is 70 km/h.

q: The driver of this car has stopped to answer the phone. Is he allowed to do that here ?
e: Waiting and Parking - Stopping to answer the phone is considered parking. On a road with a broken white line between the lanes, parking is prohibited. Only a brief stop to let someone get in or out is allowed.

q: The driver of this car has stopped to answer the phone. Is he allowed to do that here ?
e: Waiting and Parking - Stopping to answer the phone is considered parking. On a road without broken or solid white lines between the lanes, parking and stopping are allowed.

q: You have a permit to drive your car in a play street. A child wants to cross the road at a place without a pedestrian crossing. Who has the right of way ?
e: SPECIAL PLACESIn a play street, children may use the entire roadway. Anyone allowed to drive there must proceed at walking speed.

q: This driver feels safe when driving in the middle of the road. But is he allowed to do that ?
e: THE ROAD OR CARRIAGEWAY -  Drivers must drive on the right side of the road when possible. Driving in the middle or on the left without reason is a traffic violation.
optiona: Yes, but only in built-up areas.

q: Beyond which sign may you drive with a car that is 7 meters long ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - C27. No entry for drivers of vehicles whose width, including load, exceeds the indicated limit. C29. No entry for drivers of vehicles whose height, including load, exceeds the indicated limit.

q: The bell is not ringing. When are you allowed to overtake a vehicle on this level crossing ?
e: Train - Tram - Bus -  You may overtake a vehicle on the left at a level crossing when the barrier is fully open and the white lunar light is shining at the same time. But if the bell is not ringing, the barrier is open, but the lights are defective, you may also overtake a vehicle on the left.
optiona: Only if the barrier is open AND the white lunar light is lit at the same time.
optionb: If the barrier is open and the white lunar light is not lit, because it is defective.

q: You have completed 20 hours of practical lessons at a recognized driving school and received a Certificate of competence. From what age are you allowed to drive alone to practice ?
e: DRIVING LICENCE - GENERAL RULES You must have completed 20 hours of practical lessons and be 18 years old in order to drive alone with a provisional driving licence 18M.

q: Which sign indicates a cycle path ?
e: The Bicycle lane - Sign 2: mandatory sign indicating that cyclists and also pedestrians must use this part of the public road. Sign 3: bicycle zone.

q: When is a driver, when it is fairly dark outside built-up areas, allowed to keep the high beams on ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - Article 30/1 High beams must be switched off and replaced by low beams: a) when approaching an oncoming road user, b) when approaching a rail vehicle or a boat whose driver could be dazzled, c) when following another vehicle at less than 50 meters, except when overtaking, d) when the road is continuously and sufficiently lit so the driver can clearly see up to about 100 meters.
optiona: When an oncoming vehicle is approaching.
optionb: When another car is driving in front of him.
optionc: When overtaking the car in front of him.

q: The fog is slowly disappearing. Visibility is now 110 meters.
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - The rear fog light must be on in case of snowfall and fog, when visibility is less than 100 meters. In case of heavy rain, it must always be on.
optiona: The rear fog light must be on.
optionb: The rear fog light may be on.
optionc: The rear fog light must not be on.

q: Some cars are equipped with an automatic braking system.
e: STOPPING DISTANCE - You cannot rely 100% on automatic braking systems. They may trigger unexpected braking or fail to activate when needed. These technologies are driving aids that reduce the risk of accidents, but they should never replace the driver's vigilance. The driver must remain attentive and anticipate, since the technology still struggles with all road complexities.
optiona: I can fully trust this system 100%.
optionb: This allows me to be less focused while driving.
optionc: I must still remain attentive and drive anticipatively.

q: The white car has overtaken the blue car on the left. Must the driver use the indicator when moving back to the right lane ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - For every lateral movement, the indicator must be switched on. During the overtaking itself, it remains switched off.

q: Was the white car allowed to overtake the blue car here ?
e: The Lanes - The driver crossed a solid white line. That is forbidden.

q: The judge is obliged to impose a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle for speeding in a built-up area by more than ______
e: SPEED - If you exceed the maximum speed limit by more than 40 km/h on a motorway, a road for motor vehicles, or an ordinary road, you risk a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle.  In addition, if you exceed the maximum speed by more than 30 km/h in a built-up area, in a 30-zone, or in a residential area, you also risk a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle.  This is not a decision taken by the police, but by a judge in court, when your case is examined.

q: The judge is obliged to impose a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle for speeding on a motorway by more than ______
e: SPEED - If you exceed the maximum speed limit by more than 40 km/h on a motorway, a road for motor vehicles, or an ordinary road, you risk a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle. In addition, if you exceed the maximum speed by more than 30 km/h in a built-up area, in a 30-zone, or in a residential area, you also risk a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle.  This is not a decision taken by the police, but by a judge in court, when your case is examined.

q: The judge is obliged to impose a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle for speeding in a residential area by more than ______
e: SPEED - If you exceed the maximum speed limit by more than 40 km/h on a motorway, a road for motor vehicles, or an ordinary road, you risk a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle. In addition, if you exceed the maximum speed by more than 30 km/h in a built-up area, in a 30-zone, or in a residential area, you also risk a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle.  This is not a decision taken by the police, but by a judge in court, when your case is examined.

q: The judge is obliged to impose a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle for speeding on an ordinary road by more than ______
e: SPEED - If you exceed the maximum speed limit by more than 40 km/h on a motorway, a road for motor vehicles, or an ordinary road, you risk a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle. In addition, if you exceed the maximum speed by more than 30 km/h in a built-up area, in a 30-zone, or in a residential area, you also risk a revocation of the right to drive a motor vehicle.  This is not a decision taken by the police, but by a judge in court, when your case is examined.

q: The car is parked partly on the verge and partly on the roadway. Do you have to switch on the left indicator if you want to pass it ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - Normally you drive on the right side of the roadway. If you want to pass that car, you make a lateral movement to the left. Every lateral movement must be signalled with the indicator.
optionb: No, because the road is wide enough here.

q: How tall must a child be to no longer be required to sit in an appropriate safety seat ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - Children under the age of 18 and smaller than 1m35 must be transported in an appropriate safety seat or child restraint system that complies with the prescribed standards. (A child taller than 1m35 may still be transported in a special child seat). Children under 18 years old may not be transported in the front seat in a rear-facing child seat, unless there is no front airbag or the airbag can be deactivated.

q: How tall must a child be to no longer be required to sit in an appropriate safety seat ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - Children under the age of 18 and smaller than 1m35 must be transported in an appropriate safety seat or child restraint system that complies with the prescribed standards. (A child taller than 1m35 may still be transported in a special child seat). Children under 18 years old may not be transported in the front seat in a rear-facing child seat, unless there is no front airbag or the airbag can be deactivated.

q: May a child shorter than 1.35 metres sit in the front seat of the car in a special child seat, as shown here ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - Children under 18 years old and shorter than 1.35 m must be transported in an appropriate child-safety seat or restraint system that complies with legal standards. A child taller than 1.35 m may still use a child seat if desired. Children under 18 may not sit in the front in a rear-facing child seat, unless there is no front airbag or it can be deactivated.

q: The white car stopped before the intersection for safety reasons. Which car may enter the intersection first ?
e: Priority from the right - At an intersection where priority is not regulated by an authorized person, traffic lights, or signs, the rule of priority to the right applies. Even if the driver coming from the right stops first, they still keep their right of way.
optiona: The blue car, because the white one stopped.
optionb: The white car, because it comes from the right.

q: The black car stopped before the intersection for safety reasons. Which car may enter the intersection first ?
e: Priority from the right - At an intersection where priority is not regulated by an authorized person, traffic lights, or signs, the rule of priority to the right applies. Even if the driver coming from the right stops first, they still keep their right of way.
optiona: The gray car, because the black one stopped.
optionb: The black car, because it comes from the right.

q: How much lateral distance must the driver keep here when overtaking the moped rider ?
e: OVERTAKING ON THE LEFT - When overtaking a cyclist or a moped rider within built-up areas, you must keep 1 metre of lateral distance. Outside built-up areas, the distance must be at least 1.5 metres.

q: How much lateral distance must the driver keep here when overtaking the moped rider ?
e: OVERTAKING ON THE LEFT - When overtaking a cyclist or a moped rider within built-up areas, you must keep 1 metre of lateral distance. Outside built-up areas, the distance must be at least 1.5 metres.

q: How much lateral distance must the driver keep here when overtaking the cyclist ?
e: OVERTAKING ON THE LEFT - When overtaking a cyclist or a moped rider within built-up areas, you must keep 1 metre of lateral distance. Outside built-up areas, the distance must be at least 1.5 metres.

q: What is the white car allowed to do at this place ?
e: Waiting and Parking - If the carriageway is divided into lanes by a broken white line, you are only allowed to stop on the carriageway.

q: A blind bend to the left. May the white car overtake this cyclist on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - In or before a dangerous bend, it is forbidden to overtake on the left a combination of vehicles, a vehicle with more than two wheels, or a two-wheeled motor vehicle. If visibility is very poor, you are also not allowed to overtake a cyclist.

q: A roundabout, When must you switch on the right indicator ?
e: CROSSING AND TRAFFIC SIGNS - When leaving a roundabout, you must switch on the right indicator.
optionc: When entering and leaving a roundabout.

q: Is driving at too high an engine speed also harmful to the environment ?
e: Energy use - When you let your engine run unnecessarily at high revs, it consumes more fuel and emits more Corbondioxide (co2) and nitrogen oxides. This is harmful to the environment and increases engine wear, leading to higher maintenance costs.

q: There is fog and visibility is only 90 meters. The white car is parked. Which lights must be switched on ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - When you are stationary or parked on the road or on the verge: between sunset and sunrise; and whenever it is no longer possible to see clearly for about 200 meters, the following lights must be on: at the front: one or two white or yellow parking lights at the rear: one or two red lights. In foggy weather, snowfall, or heavy rain, the dipped headlights or front fog lights and also the rear fog lights may be used, but it is not required.
optiona: The parking lights at the front and rear.
optionb: The parking lights and the dipped-beam headlights.
optionc: The parking lights, dipped-beam headlights and the rear fog light.

q: What is the maximum speed allowed for the white car on this ordinary road in the Walloon Region ?
e: The Lanes - On an ordinary road, under normal conditions, the maximum permitted speed in the Walloon Region is 90 km/h. In the Flemish Region and the Brussels Region, it is 70 km/h.

q: What is the maximum speed allowed for the red car on this ordinary road in the Brussels Region ?
e: The Lanes - On an ordinary road, under normal conditions, the maximum permitted speed in the Walloon Region is 90 km/h. In the Flemish Region and the Brussels Region, it is 70 km/h.

q: The white car may stop and park on the verge under this bridge. But may a car also stop on the roadway under a bridge to let someone get out ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - It is forbidden to stop or park on the roadway under a bridge.
optionb: Yes, if there is no verge.

q: What is the blue car allowed to do at that place under a bridge ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - On the roadway under a bridge, it is forbidden to stop or park. But on the verge under a bridge, it is allowed to stop and park.

q: May the car stop at that place under the bridge to let someone get in ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - On the roadway under a bridge, it is forbidden to stop or park. But on the verge under a bridge, it is allowed to stop and park.

q: May the car stop at that place under the bridge to let someone get in ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - On the roadway under a bridge, it is forbidden to stop or park. But on the verge under a bridge, it is allowed to stop and park.

q: What can the blue car do in this location ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - On a one-way street, you can park your car on either the right or the left side

q: Inside a built-up area. What is the car allowed to do at that place ?
e: Waiting and Parking - Inside a built-up area, a car may park on a priority road. Outside a built-up area, the car must park on the verge.

q: Outside a built-up area. What is the car allowed to do at that place ?
e: Waiting and Parking - Inside a built-up area, a car may park on a priority road. Outside a built-up area, the car must park on the verge.

q: A priority road outside a built-up area. May the blue car stop on the roadway to let a passenger get in ?
e: Waiting and Parking - Inside a built-up area, you may stop on the roadway and also park there if it is not divided into lanes. Outside a built-up area, you may stop on the roadway, but not park.

q: A priority road outside a built-up area. Has this driver parked his car correctly ?
e: Waiting and Parking - Inside a built-up area, you may stop on the roadway and also park there if it is not divided into lanes. Outside a built-up area, you may stop on the roadway, but not park.

q: May the white car park at that place inside the built-up area ?
e: Waiting and Parking - The traffic sign (E1) indicates that parking is prohibited on the roadway and on the verge on this side of the road. The white arrow below the sign shows that the prohibition starts from here.

q: May the red car park at that place inside the built-up area ?
e: Waiting and Parking - The traffic sign (E1) indicates that parking is prohibited on the roadway and on the verge on this side of the road. The white arrow below the sign shows that the prohibition starts from here.

q: May this motorcycle also be parked beyond the traffic sign ?
e: Waiting and Parking - This sign means that parking is allowed for a passenger car, a dual-purpose car, a minibus, and a motorcycle. A light truck is not allowed to park there.

q: What is the maximum speed allowed for the white car on this road in the Brussels Region ?
e: EXPRESS ROAD AND REGULAR ROADS - It is a normal carriageway divided into two lanes. The maximum permitted speed in the Flemish and Brussels Regions is 70 km/h. In the Walloon Region, it is 90 km/h.

q: What is the maximum speed allowed for the white car on this road in the Walloon Region ?
e: EXPRESS ROAD AND REGULAR ROADS - It is a normal carriageway divided into two lanes. The maximum permitted speed in the Flemish and Brussels Regions is 70 km/h. In the Walloon Region, it is 90 km/h.

q: What is the maximum speed allowed for the white car on this road in the Flemish Region ?
e: EXPRESS ROAD AND REGULAR ROADS - It is a normal carriageway divided into two lanes. The maximum permitted speed in the Flemish and Brussels Regions is 70 km/h. In the Walloon Region, it is 90 km/h.

q: Both cars are driving at 50 km/h. What is the safe following distance ?
e: STOPPING DISTANCE - You can calculate this distance using a simple formula: the speed divided by two. So : 50 km/h & divide; 2 = 25 meters.

q: Both cars are driving at 70 km/h. What is the safe following distance ?
e: STOPPING DISTANCE - You can calculate this distance using a simple formula: the speed divided by two. So : 70 km/h & divide; 2 = 35 meters.

q: You are driving this car at 90 km/h. The police stop you. What are the consequences ?
e: SPEED - You risk an immediate withdrawal of your driving licence if you exceed the speed limit by more than 30 km/h on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads. If you drive in a built-up area, a 30 km/h zone or a residential area more than 20 km/h too fast, you also risk an immediate withdrawal. This immediate withdrawal is done by the police, because it is a serious offence. For any serious offence, your driving licence can be immediately withdrawn.
optionb: Your driving licence is immediately and temporarily withdrawn.
optionc: You will have to explain yourself in court.

q: An ordinary road divided into two lanes in Wallonia. You are driving this car at 110 km/h. The police stop you. What are the consequences ?
e: SPEED - You risk an immediate withdrawal of your driving licence if you exceed the speed limit by more than 30 km/h on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads. If you drive in a built-up area, a 30 km/h zone or a residential area more than 20 km/h too fast, you also risk an immediate withdrawal. This immediate withdrawal is done by the police, because it is a serious offence. For any serious offence, your driving licence can be immediately withdrawn.
optionb: Your driving licence is immediately and temporarily withdrawn.
optionc: You will have to explain yourself in court.

q: The police stopped you because you were driving at 67 km/h in a built-up area in the Brussels region. What are the consequences ?
e: SPEED - The maximum speed limit in a built-up area in the Brussels region is 30 km/h. You were therefore driving 36 km/h too fast. A driving disqualification is imposed when you exceed the limit by more than 40 km/h on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads. However, in a built-up area, a 30 km/h zone or a residential area, you already risk disqualification if you exceed the limit by more than 30 km/h. This is not done by the police but by a judge in court. Depending on the verdict, you may lose your right to drive for at least 8 days and up to 5 years, even for vehicles that do not require a driving licence. For novice drivers (with a full driving licence for less than 2 years), the rule is even stricter.
optiona: You only have to pay a fine.
optionb: Your driving licence will be temporarily withdrawn.
optionc: You will have to appear in court.

q: May you overtake a cyclist on the left on a raised section of the road inside a built-up area ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - You may overtake a cyclist or a trotinette on a raised section of the road.
optiona: Yes, if you leave 1 metre of safe lateral distance.
optionc: Yes, if you leave 1.5 metres of safe lateral distance.

q: This cyclist wants to turn left inside a built-up area. May you overtake him on the right on a raised section of the road ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - A cyclist who is about to turn left may be overtaken on the right on a raised section of the road.
optiona: Yes, if you leave 1.5 metres of safe lateral distance.
optionb: Yes, if you leave 1 metre of safe lateral distance.

q: If the air filter is dirty, does it increase fuel consumption ?
e: TECHNIQUE - A clogged or dirty air filter reduces the airflow to the engine, which increases the amount of fuel required to maintain vehicle performance. A dirty air filter therefore has a significant impact on fuel consumption, whether the vehicle runs on petrol or diesel. Depending on your vehicle and fuel type, the increase in consumption can range from 10% to 25%.

q: The driver realizes he is driving in the wrong direction. Is he allowed to turn around here ?
e: The Lanes - You are not allowed to cross a solid white line - neither to turn off nor to make a U-turn.
optionb: Yes, if he does not hinder other drivers.

q: The cyclist and the truck both want to turn right at this intersection. How does the cyclist react ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - No matter how well the mirrors are adjusted, there are always areas beside or behind the vehicle that the driver of a truck or car cannot see. These areas are called blind spots. Many accidents happen at intersections because a cyclist is in the truck's blind spot. A smart cyclist slows down and lets the truck turn first.
optiona: He hurries so that he can turn first.
optionb: He turns at the same time as the truck.
optionc: He slows down and lets the truck turn first.

q: It's warm and you're driving with the window open. Does this affect fuel consumption ?
e: Energy use - Driving with the window open affects fuel consumption. When the window is open, the vehicle's air resistance increases. At low speeds this effect is limited, but at higher speeds the added drag causes a noticeable rise in fuel consumption - up to 5-10% more at highway speed.

q: You have to drive downhill for a long distance. What should you do ?
e: TECHNIQUE - Even when driving downhill, you should engage a lower gear. Rule of thumb: descend in the same gear you would use to climb the same hill. This allows engine braking and prevents brake wear.
optiona: Let the car roll downhill in neutral.

q: What is the maximum permitted speed on a raised area within a built-up area in the Brussels-Capital Region ?
e: SPEED - Throughout the country, the maximum permitted speed on a raised area is 30 km/h, provided that it is properly signposted.

q: Are you allowed to overtake a moped rider on the left on a raised area within a built-up area ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - On a raised area, you may only overtake a cyclist on the left. (When the new traffic code comes into effect at the end of 2026, this will also be prohibited.)
optionb: Yes, if you leave one metre of lateral safety distance.

q: It is night. A driver is overtaking another car. May the high beams be on during the overtaking ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - High beams must not be used: - when the road is continuously and sufficiently lit so that you can see 100 metres ahead; - when they would dazzle an oncoming road user; - when a vehicle is driving less than 50 metres ahead of you and you are not overtaking it immediately. If you are overtaking, you may use them. - when approaching a rail vehicle or a boat.

q: Which traffic sign can replace the blue mandatory sign to obtain the same result ?
e: OBLIGATORY DIRECTION - 1 = Danger sign: succession of dangerous bends. 2 = Prohibition sign: no right turn. 3 = Danger sign: traffic allowed in both directions after a section of the road with one-way traffic.

q: Can it be dangerous to always use cruise control ?
e: SPEED - Cruise control is a feature found in most modern vehicles. It helps promote safer and more economical driving by reducing fuel consumption. Once activated, it maintains a constant speed without the driver needing to press the accelerator. However, it does not take poor road conditions into account. In cases of snow, ice, or slippery surfaces, the car's wheels can lose grip while cruise control continues to maintain the preset speed. This can cause loss of control or skidding, especially if the driver brakes suddenly to deactivate the system. In such conditions, experts strongly recommend not using cruise control to maintain full control of the vehicle

q: This boy is 1.45 metres tall.
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - Children under 18 years old and smaller than 1.35 m must be transported in an approved child restraint system that meets the required standards. A child taller than 1.35 m may still be transported in a special child seat. Children under 18 may not be transported in the front seat in a rear-facing child seat, unless there is no front airbag or it can be deactivated.
optiona: He must sit in an adapted child seat.
optionb: He may sit in an adapted child seat.
optionc: He may no longer sit in an adapted child seat

q: This girl is 12 years old and 1.45 metres tall. She is sitting in the back seat of the car and is wearing a seat belt. Is that correct ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - Children under 18 years old and smaller than 1.35 m must be transported in an approved child restraint system that meets the required standards. A child taller than 1.35 m may still be transported in a special child seat. Children under 18 may not be transported in the front seat in a rear-facing child seat, unless there is no front airbag or it can be deactivated.
optiona: Yes, because she is 1.45 metres tall.
optionb: No, she must sit in a child seat because she is only 12 years old.

q: When must the rear fog light be on ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - A car must have one or two red rear fog lights, which must be switched on: in fog, when visibility is less than about 100 metres; in snowfall, when visibility is less than about 100 metres; in heavy rain, they must always be on in Belgium.
optionb: When visibility is less than 100 metres.
optionc: When visibility is less than 50 metres.

q: If, in fog, visibility is about 110 metres...
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - A car must have one or two red rear fog lights which must be switched on: in fog, when visibility is less than about 100 metres; in snowfall, when visibility is less than about 100 metres; in heavy rain, they must always be switched on in Belgium.
optiona: the rear fog light must be on.
optionb: the rear fog light may be on.
optionc: the rear fog light may not be on.

q: What is the maximum speed allowed in Wallonia on an ordinary road when using studded tyres ?
e: The Motorway - Studded tyres may be used from 1 November to 31 March on vehicles with a maximum authorised mass of up to 3.5 tonnes. The maximum permitted speed is: - on motorways and roads with 2 times and 2 lanes separated by a central strip: 90 km/h; - on ordinary roads in all regions: 60 km/h.

q: What is the maximum speed allowed in the Flemish Region on an ordinary road when using studded tyres ?
e: The Motorway - Studded tyres may be used from 1 November to 31 March on vehicles with a maximum authorised mass of up to 3.5 tonnes. The maximum permitted speed is: - on motorways and roads with 2 times and 2 lanes separated by a central strip: 90 km/h; - on ordinary roads in all regions: 60 km/h.

q: It's snowing. When must you switch on your dipped-beam headlights ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - During the day, you must switch on your dipped-beam headlights: - in rain, when you cannot see farther than 200 metres; - in fog, when you cannot see farther than 200 metres; - in snowfall, when you cannot see farther than 200 metres; - or in other situations (e.g. smoke from a fire) when visibility is less than 200 metres.
optionb: As soon as visibility is less than 100 metres.
optionc: As soon as visibility is less than 200 metres.

q: It's snowing, when must you switch on the rear fog light ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - When you are driving, you must switch on the rear fog light: - in rain, when you cannot see farther than 100 metres; - in fog, when you cannot see farther than 100 metres; - in snowfall, when you cannot see farther than 100 metres;
optionb: As soon as visibility is less than 100 metres.
optionc: As soon as visibility is less than 200 metres.

q: Which traffic sign is associated with the road marking called shark's teeth ?
e: An inverted triangle means you must give way to drivers on the road you are about to enter and stop if necessary. If there are no drivers on the crossing road, you don't have to stop and may enter the intersection. A line formed by inverted triangles, also known as shark's teeth, indicates the place where you must stop if necessary. If it's not really necessary, you don't have to make a full stop.

q: The maximum permitted speed in this built-up area is 30 km/h. Must you give way if pedestrians cross the road ?
e: THE PEDESTRIANS - A pedestrian who wants to cross the road at a place where there is no pedestrian crossing must give way themselves. Nevertheless, drivers must always be cautious.
optiona: Yes, because the speed limit is 30 km/h.
optionb: No, they only have priority on a pedestrian crossing.

q: In areas where the speed limit is 30 km/h, pedestrians always have priority when crossing the road.
e: THE PEDESTRIANS - A pedestrian who wants to cross the road at a place where there is no pedestrian crossing must give way themselves. Nevertheless, drivers must always be cautious.

q: A one-way street in a built-up area. What is the grey car on the left side of the road allowed to do ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - On a one-way roadway, a car may be stopped or parked on either the right or the left side.

q: A one-way street in a built-up area. What is the car allowed to do at that place ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - On a one-way roadway, a car may be stopped or parked on either the right or the left side, except of course when other signs or road markings prohibit it.

q: This driver wants to turn left at this junction. Even if there are no other road users, the driver must first come to a complete stop before entering the junction.
e: CROSSING AND TRAFFIC SIGNS - The give-way sign (inverted triangle) means that you must yield to other drivers and, if necessary, come to a complete stop. If there are no other drivers, you don't need to stop completely and may enter the junction. If there is a STOP sign, however, you must come to a complete stop.

q: This driver wants to turn right at this junction. No other road users are visible. Must he switch on the right indicator ?
e: PRIORITY WHEN TURNING OFF - Every lateral movement you make must be signalled using the indicator. It doesn't matter whether there are other drivers or not.
optionb: No, if there's no one around, it's pointless.

q: This driver wants to turn right at this junction. Even if there are no other road users, the driver must first come to a complete stop before entering the junction.
e: CROSSING AND TRAFFIC SIGNS - If there is a STOP sign you must come to a complete stop. The give-way sign (inverted triangle) means that you must yield to other drivers and, if necessary, come to a complete stop.

q: Are you allowed to overtake a moped on the left with a car in a bicycle zone ?
e: In a bicycle zone, motor vehicles are not allowed to overtake a cyclist, scooter, or any other means of transport considered equivalent to a bicycle. Other vehicles (for example, a moped) may be overtaken on the left in a bicycle zone, provided that the maximum permitted speed is not exceeded.

q: In this bicycle zone, is the car allowed to overtake a cyclist ?
e: The Bicycle lane - In a bicycle zone, motor vehicles are not allowed to overtake a cyclist, scooter, or any other means of transport considered equivalent to a bicycle. Other vehicles (for example, a moped) may be overtaken on the left in a bicycle zone, provided that the maximum permitted speed is not exceeded.

q: This cyclist is 16 years old. There is no cycle path. May she ride there outside a built-up area ?
e: The Bicycle lane - If there is a cycle path, a cyclist must use it (unless it is not rideable). It is forbidden to ride a bicycle on the pavement within a built-up area, except for children under 10, who may always ride on the pavement or on the raised verge. Outside built-up areas, cyclists may, if there is no usable cycle path and provided they ride on the right-hand side of the road, ride on the pavement or on the raised verge.

q: This girl is 8 years old. She is cycling on the roadway within a built-up area. May she also ride on the raised pavement ?
e: The Bicycle lane - If there is a cycle path, a cyclist must use it (unless it is not rideable). It is forbidden to cycle on the pavement within a built-up area, except for children under 10, who may always ride on the pavement or on the raised verge. Outside built-up areas, cyclists may, if there is no usable cycle path and provided they ride on the right-hand side of the road, ride on the pavement or on the raised verge.

q: This girl is 15 years old. She is cycling on the roadway within a built-up area. May she also ride on the raised pavement ?
e: The Bicycle lane - If there is a cycle path, a cyclist must use it (unless it is not rideable). It is forbidden to cycle on the pavement within a built-up area, except for children under 10, who may always ride on the pavement or on the raised verge. Outside built-up areas, cyclists may, if there is no usable cycle path and provided they ride on the right-hand side of the road, ride on the pavement or on the raised verge.

q: What ends 100 metres further ?
e: CROSSING AND TRAFFIC SIGNS - The yellow priority sign with the supplementary sign indicates that the priority road ends 100 metres further. At the next junction, you will have to give way.

q: May this car park at that place ?
e: Waiting and Parking - You are not allowed to park outside built-up areas on the carriageway of a priority road. Stopping, however, is allowed.
optiona: Yes, because the roadway is not divided into lanes.
optionb: No, because it is outside the built-up area.

q: What is the maximum speed allowed in the Walloon region on this road after passing the yellow sign ?
e: SPEED - It is a normal roadway divided into two lanes. In the Walloon Region, the maximum permitted speed is 90 km/h. In the Flemish and Brussels Regions, it is 70 km/h. The yellow sign has nothing to do with speed - it is a priority-road sign indicating that you are driving on a priority road.

q: This roadway is divided into two lanes. What is the maximum speed allowed in the Brussels Region after passing the yellow sign ?
e: SPEED - It is a normal roadway divided into two lanes. In the Walloon Region, the maximum permitted speed is 90 km/h. In the Flemish and Brussels Regions, it is 70 km/h. The yellow sign has nothing to do with speed - it is a priority-road sign indicating that you are driving on a priority road.

q: At what maximum speed may this car drive past the yellow sign within a built-up area in the Brussels Region ?
e: SPEED - It is a roadway within a built-up area. In the Walloon and Flemish Regions, the maximum permitted speed inside built-up areas is 50 km/h. In the Brussels Region, it is 30 km/h. The yellow sign has nothing to do with speed - it is a priority-road sign indicating that you are driving on a priority road.

q: At what maximum speed may this car drive past the yellow sign within a built-up area in the Walloon Region ?
e: SPEED - It is a roadway within a built-up area. In the Walloon and Flemish Regions, the maximum permitted speed inside built-up areas is 50 km/h. In the Brussels Region, it is 30 km/h. The yellow sign has nothing to do with speed - it is a priority-road sign indicating that you are driving on a priority road.

q: At what maximum speed may this car drive past this sign in the Brussels-Capital Region ?
e: SPECIAL PLACESThis traffic sign indicates the end of a built-up area. The maximum permitted speed outside built-up areas is: - in the Flemish Region and the Brussels-Capital Region: 70 km/h - in the Walloon Region: 90 km/h

q: At what maximum speed may this car drive, inside a built-up area in the Walloon Region, past this sign ?
e: SPECIAL PLACESThis sign indicates, inside a built-up area, the end of a 30 km/h zone. The car therefore continues within the built-up area. The maximum permitted speed inside built-up areas is: - in the Flemish Region and the Walloon Region: 50 km/h - in the Brussels-Capital Region: 30 km/h

q: At what maximum speed may this car drive, inside a built-up area in the Flemish Region, past this sign ?
e: SPECIAL PLACESThis sign indicates, inside a built-up area, the end of a 30 km/h zone. The car therefore continues within the built-up area. The maximum permitted speed inside built-up areas is: - in the Flemish Region and the Walloon Region: 50 km/h - in the Brussels-Capital Region: 30 km/h

q: Nighttime, outside a built-up area. Before starting to overtake, the driver of the blue car briefly used the horn. Was he allowed to do that ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - When may you use the horn ? - During the day: Inside and outside built-up areas: to warn others and prevent an accident. Outside built-up areas: to warn a driver you intend to overtake. - Between dusk and dawn: Only in case of imminent danger. In all other cases, you must flash your headlights alternately instead of using the horn.
optionb: Yes, because it is outside the built-up area.

q: It is night, outside a built-up area. While the blue car is overtaking, the distracted driver of the white car suddenly swerves to the left. What may the driver of the blue car do ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - When may you use the horn ? During the day: Inside and outside built-up areas: to warn others and prevent an accident. Outside built-up areas: to warn a driver you intend to overtake. Between dusk and dawn: Only in case of imminent danger. In all other cases, you must flash your headlights alternately instead of using the horn.
optiona: He may only use the main beams because it is night.
optionb: He may use the horn to avoid an accident.

q: It is dusk inside a built-up area. Before the driver of the white car started overtaking, he briefly flashed the high beams. Was he allowed to do that ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - When may you use the horn ? During the day: Inside and outside built-up areas: to warn others and prevent an accident. Outside built-up areas: to warn a driver you intend to overtake. Between dusk and dawn: Only in case of imminent danger. In all other cases, instead of using the horn, you should flash the headlights (switch between high and low beams).
optionb: No, because he is driving inside a built-up area.

q: May the car overtake the truck on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - The red circular prohibition sign indicates that drivers are forbidden to: - overtake a combination of vehicles, or - overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - it ends earlier if you see the end-of-prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a two-wheeled motorcycle. But the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.

q: May the motorcycle overtake the truck on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - The red circular prohibition sign indicates that drivers are forbidden to: - overtake a combination of vehicles, or - overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - it ends earlier if you see the end-of-prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a two-wheeled motorcycle. But the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.

q: May the motorcycle overtake the motorcycle on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - The red circular prohibition sign indicates that drivers are forbidden to: - overtake a combination of vehicles, or - overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - it ends earlier if you see the end-of-prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a two-wheeled motorcycle. But the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.

q: May the car overtake the truck on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - This prohibition sign indicates that trucks or combinations with a maximum authorised mass exceeding 3500 kg may not overtake: - a combination of vehicles, or - any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - ends earlier if you see the end of overtaking prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a truck on the left after this sign. A bus may also overtake, since it is not a truck.

q: May the car overtake the truck on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - The red circular prohibition sign indicates that drivers are forbidden to: - overtake a combination of vehicles, or - overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels. The blue sign indicates that the overtaking prohibition begins 200 metres further ahead.

q: A roadway not divided into lanes inside a built-up area. May the red car overtake the white car on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - This prohibition sign indicates that trucks or combinations with a maximum authorised mass exceeding 3500 kg may not overtake: - a combination of vehicles, or - any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - ends earlier if you see the end of overtaking prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a truck on the left after this sign. A bus may also overtake, since it is not a truck.

q: A roadway divided into lanes inside a built-up area. May the white car overtake the blue car on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - The red circular prohibition sign indicates that it is forbidden for drivers to: - overtake a combination of vehicles, or - overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - ends earlier if you see the end of overtaking prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a two-wheeled motorcycle, but the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.

q: A roadway divided into lanes outside a built-up area. May the red truck overtake the white car on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - This prohibition sign indicates that trucks or combinations with a maximum authorised mass exceeding 3500 kg may not overtake: - a combination of vehicles, or - any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - ends earlier if you see the end of overtaking prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a truck on the left after this sign. A bus may also overtake, since it is not a truck.

q: May the truck overtake the blue car on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - The red circular prohibition sign indicates that it is forbidden for drivers to: - overtake a combination of vehicles, or - overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - ends earlier if you see the end of overtaking prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a two-wheeled motorcycle, but the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.
optiona: Yes, because a truck is not a passenger car.

q: May the truck overtake the blue car on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - The overtaking prohibition begins within 200 metres. The red circular prohibition sign indicates that it is forbidden for drivers to: - overtake a combination of vehicles, or - overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - ends earlier if you see the end of overtaking prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a two-wheeled motorcycle, but the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.

q: May the truck overtake a horse rider on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - This prohibition sign indicates that trucks or combinations with a maximum authorised mass exceeding 3500 kg may not overtake: - a combination of vehicles, or - any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - ends earlier if you see the end of overtaking prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a truck on the left after this sign. A bus may also overtake, since it is not a truck.

q: May the car overtake the horse-drawn cart on the left ?
e: OVER TAKING ON THE LEFT PROHIBITED - The red circular prohibition sign indicates that it is forbidden for drivers to: - overtake a combination of vehicles, or - overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels. The no-overtaking rule applies: - up to and including the next intersection, or - ends earlier if you see the end of overtaking prohibition sign. A car driver may therefore overtake a two-wheeled motorcycle, but the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.

q: How far may an indivisible load extend in front of the car without any signalling ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - A load may never extend beyond the front of the vehicle. Keep this in mind if you ever transport a ladder on the roof rack. At the rear, it may extend up to 1 metre.

q: How far may an indivisible load extend in front of the car, without any signalling ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - A load may never extend beyond the front of the vehicle. Keep this in mind if you ever transport a ladder on the roof rack. At the rear, it may extend up to 1 metre.

q: How far may this pipe extend beyond the rear of the vehicle ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - A load may extend up to 1 metre beyond the rear of the vehicle. If you must carry a load that is indivisible or cannot be shortened or folded, it may extend up to 3 metres beyond the rear, provided that a warning panel is attached at the end of the load.

q: How far may this pipe extend beyond the rear of the vehicle ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - A load may extend up to 1 metre beyond the rear of the vehicle. If you must carry a load that is indivisible or cannot be shortened or folded, it may extend up to 3 metres beyond the rear, provided that a warning panel is attached at the end of the load.

q: How far may an indivisible load extend beyond the rear of the vehicle if it is properly marked ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - A load may extend up to 1 metre beyond the rear of the vehicle. If the load is indivisible and cannot be shortened or folded, it may extend up to 3 metres beyond the rear, provided that it is properly marked with the required warning panel. This load is not properly marked.

q: In a van, the front seat can accommodate the driver and two passengers. What must be the minimum width of that seat ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - The width must be sufficient for: Driver: 55 cm. Each passenger: 40 cm. Total: 55 + 40 + 40 = 135 cm.

q: The fuel of your car is LPG or petrol. Are you allowed to drive past this sign ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - This sign has nothing to do with the fuel your car uses. It concerns the load you are carrying. Prohibition sign C24b: no entry for drivers of vehicles transporting flammable or explosive substances.
optionc: Yes, provided you switch from LPG to petrol.

q: This truck is carrying tons of washing powder. May it drive past this sign ?
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - Meaning of sign C24a: No entry for drivers of vehicles carrying dangerous goods. Washing powder is not a dangerous substance.

q: This sign indicates that drivers of certain (______) are not allowed to drive their vehicle past this sign.
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - Meaning of sign C24a: No entry for drivers of vehicles carrying dangerous goods.

q: Up to how many metres before a pedestrian crossing is it forbidden to park on the roadway ?
e: THE PEDESTRIANS - It is forbidden to park or stop on a pedestrian crossing, even to let someone get in or out. It is also forbidden to park or to stop on the roadway within 5 metres before the crossing (parking on the verge is allowed if possible). The same rule applies to crossings for cyclists and two-wheeled mopeds. After the crossing, parking and stopping are allowed, unless prohibited by traffic signs.

q: May the car stop at that place within a built-up area to let a passenger get in ?
e: THE PEDESTRIANS - It is forbidden to park or stop on a pedestrian crossing, even to let someone get in or out. It is also forbidden to park or to stop on the roadway within 5 metres before the crossing (parking on the verge is allowed if possible). The same rule applies to crossings for cyclists and two-wheeled mopeds. After the crossing, parking and stopping are allowed, unless prohibited by traffic signs.

q: A car may not park on the roadway within 5 metres before a pedestrian or cyclist crossing. But may a driver stop there to let someone get in ?
e: THE PEDESTRIANS - It is forbidden to park or stop on a pedestrian crossing, even to let someone get in or out. It is also forbidden to park or stop on the roadway within 5 metres before the crossing (parking on the verge is allowed if possible). The same rule applies to crossings for cyclists and two-wheeled mopeds. After the crossing, parking and stopping are allowed, unless prohibited by traffic signs.

q: A car may not park on the roadway within 5 metres before a pedestrian or cyclist crossing. But may a driver stop there to let someone get in ?
e: THE PEDESTRIANS - It is forbidden to park or stop on a pedestrian crossing, even to let someone get in or out. It is also forbidden to park or stop on the roadway within 5 metres before the crossing (parking on the verge is allowed if possible). The same rule applies to crossings for cyclists and two-wheeled mopeds. After the crossing, parking and stopping are allowed, unless prohibited by traffic signs.

q: A driver has parked his car very badly. But is he allowed to park there ?
e: Waiting and Parking - You may not park (but you may stop) next to a broken yellow line painted along the edge of the roadway.
optiona: Yes, because there is a broken yellow line.
optionb: No, because there is a broken yellow line.

q: Is this lorry allowed to park on the roadway ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - If you see this sign, it means you must park on the verge. Parking on the roadway is not permitted.

q: May this lorry park in that place ?
e: The traffic sign with the symbol of a lorry indicates that it is a location where lorries are allowed to park. A car may stop briefly there to let a passenger get in or out.

q: Is this lorry parked correctly ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - The blue sign indicates that vehicles must park partly on the roadway and partly on the verge.
optiona: Yes, because the roadway is not divided into lanes.

q: Is this car parked correctly ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - The blue sign indicates that vehicles must park partly on the roadway and partly on the verge.

q: When you see this road sign, it means that all motor vehicles, including lorries, may park beyond the sign.
e: WAITING AND PARKING - The road sign with the symbol of a lorry indicates a parking place reserved only for lorries. Other motor vehicles, such as cars, are not allowed to park there. However, a car may stop there briefly to let a passenger get in or out.

q: Dad is walking in the street with his son who is sitting on a pony. Dad is ______
e: THE PEDESTRIANS - A rider or a person who leads a horse is not a pedestrian, but a driver under the traffic rules.

q: This prohibition sign relates to the maximum (______) of a vehicle, load included.
e: LOAD AND PASSENGER SEAT - Because some bridges or tunnels are lower, this sign may impose a different maximum height. Truck and bus drivers have often learned the hard way that this sign is not placed without reason.

q: You park your car at 15:06 in a street where you must use a parking disc. At what time do you set the arrow ?
e: WAITING AND PARKING - On the parking disc, you set the arrow to the mark that follows your arrival time. The mark after 15:06 is 15:30. You may then park for two hours, counted from the time shown by the arrow, unless a traffic sign specifies a different duration. After that, you must move your car - you may not simply change the time on the parking disc.

q: You parked your car in a street and spent the night at your grandparents' house. The next morning you want to leave, but the street has become a school street. Are you allowed to drive away ?
e: SPECIAL PLACES - To reduce traffic congestion at the start and end of the school day, a street near a school may be closed twice a day to motor vehicles. When this happens, the street becomes a school street. This is indicated by a C3 (no entry) traffic sign, together with an additional panel stating SCHOOL STREET. Who may enter a school street ? - Pedestrians, cyclists, and speed pedelecs. - Residents of the street or drivers who have a garage there (with a permit). - Priority vehicles. - Vehicles with a special permit.
optiona: Yes, but only at walking speed.

q: At what maximum permitted speed may the car continue on this road in Flanders after passing this sign ?
e: SPECIAL PLACESThe yellow sign is a town-name sign. It only indicates that you are entering the territory of a municipality; it does not mark the start of a built-up area. In Flanders and Brussels region, the maximum permitted speed on an ordinary road is 70 km/h. In Wallonia the speed limit is 90 km/h.

q: An accident without injuries. What should you do if one of the drivers refuses to sign the European accident report ?
e: Accidents - In an accident without injuries, you normally do not need to call the police, but the European accident report must be completed and signed by all drivers involved. By signing, you confirm that you agree with the information written on the form. Once everyone has signed, nothing can be changed. If one of the drivers refuses to sign the report, you call the police.
optiona: You sign it and inform the insurance company.

q: A cyclist has been hit at an intersection and is lying unconscious on the ground. Are you allowed to clear the intersection and carefully carry the cyclist to the side of the road ?
e: Accidents - In an accident with injured persons, you leave the injured where they are and call the emergency services. If there are injured persons, the police must also come to make the official report.
optiona: Yes, you must clear the intersection.
optionb: No, an injured person must remain where they are.

q: After which traffic sign can you commit a 4th-degree offence ?
e: 4th-degree offence Fourth-degree offences are the most serious traffic violations. They directly endanger the safety of people and, in a collision, almost inevitably lead to physical injury. Examples include: -> ignoring the orders of an authorised person, ->  not respecting the signalling at a level crossing, ->  stopping or parking a vehicle on a level crossing, ->  encouraging excessive speed, ->  organising or taking part in speed races on public roads, ->  overtaking on the left on a hill or in a bend when prohibited, ->  reversing or driving in the opposite direction on a motorway or an expressway.

q: Driving onto a level crossing when the red flashing light is operating and the barrier is descending is an offence of the ______
e: The Motorway / Offences Fourth-degree offences are the most serious traffic violations. They directly endanger people's safety and, in the event of a collision, almost inevitably cause physical injury. Examples include: - ignoring the orders of an authorised person, - not respecting the signalling at a level crossing, - stopping or parking on a level crossing, - encouraging excessive speed, - organising speed races on public roads, - overtaking on the left on a hill or in a bend when this is prohibited, - reversing or driving in the opposite direction on a motorway or expressway.

q: You are driving at 47 km/h in a residential area in Wallonia. What are the consequences ?
e: SPEED - You risk an immediate withdrawal of your driving licence as soon as you drive more than 30 km/h too fast on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads. However, in a built-up area, a 30 km/h zone, or a residential area (woonerf), you already risk an immediate withdrawal if you drive more than 20 km/h too fast. You risk a disqualification from driving as soon as you exceed the speed limit by more than 40 km/h on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads. In a built-up area, a 30 km/h zone or a residential area, you already receive a disqualification once you exceed the speed limit by more than 30 km/h. This is not decided by the police but by the judge when your case is handled in court.
optionb: You receive an immediate temporary withdrawal of your driving licence.
optionc: You will have to appear before the court.

q: When are you required to use your direction indicator ?
e: CROSSING AND TRAFFIC SIGNS - When entering a roundabout, you may use your indicator, but it is not mandatory. When leaving a roundabout, you must use the right indicator to show that you are exiting.
optiona: When entering and leaving a roundabout.

q: There is heavy rain and visibility is reduced to 130 metres. Must the rear fog lights be switched on ?
e: THE LIGHTS AND THE HORN - The rear fog light must be switched on: in fog, when visibility is less than about 100 metres; in snowfall, when visibility is less than about 100 metres; in heavy rain, it must always be on in Belgium, regardless of visibility.
optionb: No, because visibility is more than 100 metres.
optionc: Rear fog lights are never compulsory.

q: After a breath test, your result is 0.25 mg/l. What happens ?
e: Alcohol - Drugs - In a breath analysis, you blow into a device that measures the alcohol concentration in the alveolar air you exhale. The exact result appears on the screen (e.g. 0.25 mg/l). - Less than 0.22 mg/l: you may continue to drive. - 0.22 to less than 0.35 mg/l: you must surrender your licence for 3 hours. This is an offence and you will receive a fine. - 0.35 mg/l or more: you must surrender your licence for 6 hours. An immediate withdrawal is possible. After those 6 hours, a new breath test is required.
optiona: You may leave because this is below the limit.

q: From how many cyclists in a group are two road captains required ?
e: The Bicycle lane - Cyclists riding in a group of 51 to 150 participants must be accompanied by two road captains. They are not required to use the cycle paths and may ride two abreast on the roadway, provided the group stays together.

q: The police stop you in a built-up area in Flanders because you were driving at 75 km/h. What are the consequences ?
e: SPEED - You risk an immediate withdrawal of your licence as soon as you drive more than 30 km/h too fast on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads. But in built-up areas, 30 km/h zones, or residential areas, you already risk this when you drive more than 20 km/h too fast. You risk a driving disqualification as soon as you exceed the speed limit by more than 40 km/h on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads. In built-up areas, 30 km/h zones, or residential areas, you already receive a disqualification once you exceed the limit by more than 30 km/h. This is decided by the judge, not by the police.
optionb: You receive an immediate temporary withdrawal of your driving licence.
optionc: You will have to appear before the court.

q: After which signs do you have priority ?
e: CROSSING AND TRAFFIC SIGNS - Sign 1 - B21: Narrow passage. You have priority over traffic coming from the opposite direction. - Sign 2 - A39: Two-way traffic after a one-way section. This sign does not grant priority. - Sign 3 - B19: Narrow passage. You must give priority to oncoming traffic - so you do not have priority.

q: During a police check, you realise that you forgot your wallet with your driving licence at home. What are the consequences ?
e: INFO - DRIVING LICENCE - Not carrying your driving licence with you is not considered a serious offence. You may receive a small administrative fine, but you are generally allowed to continue driving. However, you must present your licence at a police station within 5 days. If your licence is lost or stolen, you may not drive until you receive a new one. A loss or theft certificate is not sufficient to allow you to drive.
optiona: You are not allowed to continue driving.
optionb: You only receive a first-degree fine.
optionc: You must show your driving licence at a police station within 5 days.

q: You are approaching an intersection where a police officer is standing with one arm raised. What do you do ?
e: THE AUTHORIZED PERSON - When a police officer raises one arm vertically at an intersection, all road users must stop. Anyone already on the intersection must leave it as quickly as possible.
optiona: You slow down and wait for the order he will give.

q: Just as you enter an intersection, a police officer raises one arm vertically. What do you do ?
e: THE AUTHORIZED PERSON - When a police officer raises one arm vertically at an intersection, all road users must stop. Anyone already on the intersection must leave it as quickly as possible.
optiona: You slow down and wait for the order he will give.
optionc: You continue driving and leave the intersection.

q: You are approaching an intersection where an officer is standing with one arm extended horizontally. What instruction is the officer giving ?
e: THE AUTHORIZED PERSON - When an officer extends one or both arms horizontally, road users approaching the officer's chest or back must stop.
